Name: Angediva Island
Description:
Anjediva Island (also Anjadip Island) (Goan Konkani: Anjadiv; Portuguese: Ilha de Angediva) is an Indian island in the Arabian Sea. It sits off the coast of Canacona, Goa. It is politically part of Goa state, geographically the nearest mainland is the coastal Kanara subregion of Carnataca.

The island is about 1.8 kilometres (1 mile) south of Goa, and extends over 1.5 square kilometres (1 square mile). It was part of the Portuguese Indian settlements until 1961, following the annexation of Goa and Damaon the place was turned into a military base, after which the civilian population was resettled to India or returned to Portugal.

The island is home to the Portuguese-built Anjediva fortress, which houses the shrines of Our Lady of Brotas and São Francisco de Assis. The island is connected to the mainland by a breakwater and is part of INS Kadamba Naval Base, on the outskirts of the city of Karwar and hence under the jurisdiction of the Indian Navy.

Name: Kodibag Beach
Description:
At a distance of 4.5 km from Karwar Bus Stand and 3 km from Devbagh Beach, Kodibag Beach or Koodi Bagh Beach is located at the confluence of the Kali River and the Arabian Sea in Karwar.

Koodi Bagh is among the most beautiful shorelines of Karwar and also one of the tourist places in Karwar. The meeting point of the Kali River and the Arabian Sea is a spectacular sight to watch. This beach is situated at the northern end of the Karwar Beach.

This beach offers an amazing view of sunset. It is good to have a relaxing time with some fun at this Beach. Long leisurely walks in the cool beach sands will be a soothing experience. This beach is very clean and is a perfect destination for adventure lovers. At this palm-fringed beach various activities such as canoeing, kayaking, paddling, banana boat riding and many more can be enjoyed.

Name: INS Chapal (K94) Warship Museum
Description: Located at a distance of 1 km from the city centre in Karwar, INS Chapal Warship Museum is situated in Rabindranath Tagore beach. INS Chapal is a missile warship and was used in the 1971 Indo - Pak war. In 2006, the ship was converted into a museum to display sea-artefacts, a video of the ship being converted into this museum among other collectibles.

Name: Guddehalli Gudda
Description:
Once a summer retreat for the British, Guddalli Peak is one of the tallest peaks of the Haidarghat mountain range. A blessing in disguise, Guddali Peak is one of the highest peaks of the area. With an average altitude of about 1800 ft above the sea level, the peak offers a splendid top view of the dense foliage, River Kali, River Belikeri and the Arabian Sea at a distance.

With amazing weather throughout the year and flanked by a thick cover of woods and river meandering through the region, the peak is approachable by a trek of 5 kms crossing several springs and brooks. It is located nearly 13 kms from Devbagh.

Name: Half Moon Beach
Description:
Half Moon Beach is a small beach situated in Gokarna. It is separated from the Om Beach by a cliff from where tourists are bound to get an amazing view of the Arabian Sea. Numerous village huts in the classical Indian style can be spotted lined up by the beach giving it a rather traditional and homely touch altogether. The beach got its name from the striking resemblance that it exhibits with a half moon. Away from the civilization and into the arms of nature, this is the best place to spend time at while looking at the caves and gazing at the sky lit with stars.

Being at the beach is one of the most thrilling experiences as when you are bathing in the water of the Half Moon, all you can see ahead of you is the infinite ocean and behind is the lush and thick jungle making you feel as if you are the last living person left on the face of the earth. There are numerous exciting activities that the place offers including swimming, canoeing, paddle boats, paintball, camping, and cabins. However, there are no water sports available as such. Tourists can also unwind by going sunbathing in the afternoon and lying on hammocks in the night.

To add more to the list, the food of the shack restaurants is finger-licking good. Overseeing the entire coast of the Om Beach, the Half Moon Beach is definitely a getaway spot for all the travellers out there to travel away from the hustle and bustle of the city into nature's lap.

Review 2: This is one among the 2 beaches of Gokarna where you can reach through Trekking or a ferry.. We initially took the trekking path.. Started our trek from Belekan beach, moved to Paradise and then landed at this beautiful secluded place

Name: Paradise Beach
Description:
The fourth beach lying across the coast of Gokarna Town, Paradise Beach is also well-known by the name of 'Full Moon Beach'. Located in the state of Karnataka, the Paradise Beach is about 150 meters in length and out of this almost seventy percent of the beach is entirely covered in rocks. The rest of the beach is adorned with clean white sand all over. Not much water sports are available here but swimming in the calm waters here is a great way to refresh your mind and body. The serene environment of the beach offers a great opportunity to spend some time in nature's lap and find solace.

Paradise Beach is not accessible by road and can only be reached via other beaches, namely the Half Moon Beach and Om Beach. Visitors need to hire a motor boat from either of the above-stated beaches to reach the Paradise Beach. This beach can also be reached after a small hike from the Half Moon Beach. Via this route, it will not take you more than 20 minutes to reach. Paradise Beach was earlier known as the hot spot for all the hippies, due to the trade of weed going on here. As soon as this caught the eye of the Government authorities, all these antisocial activities were curbed, shacks were broken, and all kinds of commercial activities were prohibited here.

During the night time, you can often spot small troops of foreign travellers staying here, camping and cooking their meals. Availability of fresh water well on the beach makes it an ideal spot for camping. The water from this well is clean and safe for drinking. Name: Gadaikallu (Narasimha Gudde)
Description: Gadaikallu, also known as Narasimha Gudde, is a hill located in the Western Ghats of Karnataka, India. It is situated in the Belthangady taluk of Dakshina Kannada district, about 70 kilometers from Mangalore. The hill is about 1,788 feet (545 meters) high and is known for its scenic beauty and religious significance. The name Gadaikallu comes from the Kannada words "gada" (mace) and "kallu" (stone). The hill is said to resemble a mace, and there is a temple dedicated to Lord Narasimha, an incarnation of Vishnu, on the top of the hill. The hill is a popular trekking destination, and the trek to the top is about 4 kilometers long. The trek is moderately difficult and takes about 2-3 hours to complete. The views from the top of the hill are breathtaking, and on a clear day, one can see the Arabian Sea and the Kudremukh National Park. The temple on the top of the hill is said to have been built by the Keladi Nayaks in the 16th century. The temple is small and simple, but it is a popular pilgrimage destination. Gadaikallu is a beautiful and peaceful place, and it is a great place to go for a trek or a pilgrimage.

Name: Malpe Island Fort
Description:
The Malpe Island Fort, also known as Daria Bahadurgad Fort, is a historical landmark located near Malpe beach in Karnataka, India. Here's a breakdown of its key aspects:

Built by Basavappa Naik of Bidanur, the fort's exact construction date remains unclear, though historical estimates place it in the "past decades."
It likely served a defensive purpose, protecting the Malpe coast from potential maritime attacks.
The fort lies on Daria-Bahadurgad Island, a small rocky island about 1.6 square kilometers wide, situated a few kilometers west of Malpe beach.
Malpe town is well-connected by road to Udupi, the nearest major city.
Reaching the fort involves taking a boat ride from Malpe; these services are readily available and affordable.

Name: Nellithirtha Shree Somanatheswara Guhalaya
Description:
Nellitheertha Cave Temple in Nellitheertha, Karnataka, India is dedicated to the Indian deity Sri Somanatheshwara, or Shiva. The temple dates back to at least 1487 CE.
Lord Somanatha ,To the right of the temple is a natural cave, about 200 metres (660 ft) long. Access is restricted, forcing visitors to crawl in on their knees. Inside, there is a lake and a Shiva Lingam.It is believed that the cave in Nellitheertha was used by Sage Jabali to perform a penance to appease Goddess Durga Parameshwari. Goddess Durga appeared in front of Sage Jabali and assured him that she would kill the demon Arunasura. She later took the shape of a bumble bee and killed Arunasura on the banks of the river Nandini. At that place today is a beautiful temple of Goddess Durgaparameshwari and the place is very well known as Kateel.

The Cave at Nellitheertha.
Goddess Durga also assured Sage Jabali that Shiva, Vishnu and Durga herself would grace that region and that there would be temples to worship all three of them in the vicinity. One can find a Vishnu temple near Nellitheertha at a place called Kompadavu. Goddess Durga is worshipped in a place called Muchur, again near Nellitheertha. And Lord Shiva made Nellitheertha his abode.

Name: Adyar Falls
Description: Adyar Falls, also known as Adyar Waterfalls, is a seasonal waterfall located near Mangalore, Karnataka, India.It's a relatively small waterfall, and its water level fluctuates significantly depending on the season. During the monsoon season (June to September), the falls come alive with a stronger flow, while the dry season might see them reduced to a trickle or even completely dry. Reaching the falls requires a short trek, which may not be suitable for everyone, especially during the monsoon when the path can get slippery.

Name: Narasimhaghada-Jamalabad Fort-Gadayikal
Description:
Narasimhaghada-Jamalabad Fort-Gadayikal, also known as Jamalabad Fort and Gadaikallu, is a hilltop fort located in the Kudremukh range of hills, 8 km north of Beltangady town and 65 km from the city of Mangalore in Dakshina Kannada district, Karnataka, India.

The fort is believed to have been built by the Keladi Nayaks in the 16th century, and was later captured by Tipu Sultan in the 18th century. The fort is now in ruins, but still offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape.

The fort is situated on a hill that is about 300 meters high. The main entrance to the fort is on the eastern side. The fort has two main gates, the outer gate and the inner gate. The outer gate is smaller and has a smaller tower. The inner gate is larger and has a larger tower. The fort has several other towers and bastions.

The fort is in ruins, but still offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape. The fort is a popular tourist destination, and is known for its historical significance and scenic beauty.

Name: Yana Rocks
Description:
Yana is a tourist destination located in forest of Katgal Range, which is also a part of Malenadu region of Uttara Kannada district of Karnataka state in India . Yana is one of the wettest villages in the world. It is the cleanest village in Karnataka and the second cleanest village in India. The two unique rock outcrops after the village are tourist attractions and easily approachable by two routes one from Kumta-Sirsi Highway by a small trek through 0.5 kilometres (0.31 mi) the thick forests from the nearest road head and another from Sirsi-Ankola Road.

Yana is famous for these two massive rock outcrops known as the Bhairaveshwara Shikhara and the Mohini Shikhara ("Shikhara" means "mountain peak"). The huge rocks are composed of solid black, crystalline karst limestone. Bhairaveshwara Shikhara is 120 metres (390 ft) in height, while the Mohini Shikhara, which is smaller, is 90 metres (300 ft) in height. Yana is also well known as a pilgrimage center because of the cave temple below the Bhairaveshwara Shikhara where a Swayambhu ("self-manifested", or "that which is created by its own accord") linga has been formed. Water drips from the roof over the Linga, adding to the sanctity of the place. During Shivaratri here, a car festival is held, along with other festivities. The place and its surrounding hillocks are also known for their evergreen scenic forests.

Name: Mirjan Fort
Description:
The Mirjan Fort is located on the west coast of the Uttara Kannada district in the southern Indian state of Karnataka. The fort known for its architectural elegance was the location of several battles in the past. It is about 0.5 kilometres (0.31 mi) from the National Highway 66 and 21 kilometres (13 mi) from Gokarna, the famous Hindu pilgrimage centre on the west coast of India.

According to the first historical version, Rani Chennabhairadevi of Gersoppa (under the Vijayanagara Empire) was initially credited with building the Mirjan Fort in the 16th century. She ruled for 54 years and also lived in the fort. During her reign, the port at Mirjan, which is 32 kilometres (20 mi) to the south east of Karwar, was used for shipping pepper, saltpetre and betel nut to Surat. Gersoppa, a district annexed to Bednur, was famous for the pepper exported from this region. Consequently, the Portuguese gave the epithet "Rani, the Pepper queen" ("Rainha de Pimenta" in Portuguese) to the Queen of Gersoppa.

Name: Gokarna Main Beach

It has recently gained popularity as a go-to beach destination owing to its beautiful stretches of sand and pristine locations. Walking along the coastline here is unique as you will come across many cafes and shacks and this is a place where the hippie culture of Gokarna is at.

 It is quite popular with pilgrims who come to the town to seek the blessings of Shiva, Indian groups and with foreign tourists as well. The muddy uphill roads with forest cover on both sides provide for more than a reason to go for a hike or a family picnic. The steep rocks in the shallow sea allow rock climbing for the adventure junkies. Bird and animal life is plenty around the serene beaches. While in Gokarna Beach, taking a crash course in Yoga is also a great way to spend the mornings.

Name: Mahatma Gandhi Museum
Description:
The Mahatma Gandhi museum played a crucial role in galvanizing the freedom struggle in the city. On his visits, Mahatma Gandhi enjoyed enlightening people and participating in various school functions. Once in 1927, Ganghiji inaugurated a portrait of Lokmanya Tilak, a celebrated freedom fighter, in the Canara Public School, Dongerkery. His next visit to the school was in 1934. This visit was accompanied by Gandhiji laying the foundation of the Krishna Mandir.

The school authorities sought his permission (in 1939) to name the museum, which came into existence in 1935, after his name (although Gandhiji was confused as to what purpose it would serve – a humble man indeed!). Presently the museum stands in the school premises and is indeed an honor to the eminent leader of all times, Mahatma Gandhi.

Name: Aloyseum (St Aloysius museum)
Description: This museum began in 1913 when an Italian Jesuit priest named Chiapi donated around 2000 different types of minerals, Herbarium and a collection of Roman coins. In 1906, the De Dion car was the first automobile that was used in Mangalore. It was imported to Mangalore by P F X Saldanha of the Highland Coffee Works. This car is one of the souvenirs present in this museum. The museum also has a collection of domestic and agricultural utensils used by the ancient generation.This museum contains artifacts such as stone age tools, postal stamps, Roman coins, pieces of the Berlin Wall, drawings of Antonio Moscheni, paintings of European artists, spears and arrows of Abyssinia, Neolithic stone axe, telegraphic equipment, Mangalore's first car and generator, whale skeleton, old musical instruments, etc.

Name: Guthu House pilikula Heritage village
Description: Like all other districts, Dakshina Kannada district too is rich in heritage and culture. Spread across 350 acres, Pilikula Nisargadham offers an array of activities one can think of. Botanical Garden, Medicinal Garden, Guthu Mane, Pottery, Handloom,Blacksmith, nursery, and Folklore gallery are the few main attractions of the Pilikula Nisargadham. Dakshina Kannada’s economy primarily depends on tourism, agriculture, and its by-products. The region is bestowed with heritage, culture, and historical marvels. At Pilikula Nisargadham, after deep research on the village and cultural aspects, a heritage village is recreated. This heritage village facilitates the visitors on how the various activities like handloom, pottery making, black-smithy, stone carving, carpentry, and many other hand-crafted activities are performed. This gives visitors a first-hand experience of the various rural activities.

Name: Pandava Cave
Description: The Pandava Caves are located near Kadri Manjunath temple in Mangalore, Karnataka, India. Historians found that the current temple was a Buddhist monastery known as Kandarika Vihara. The shrine had a standing Buddha image in it. This image was replaced by the King Kundvarma of the Alupa dynasty, who was a devotee of Shiva. However it was not the Buddha but a bodhisattva who was historically integrated with Shiva. Historians concluded that the vihara was originally a centre of the cult of the bodhisattva Manjusri. This temple was one of the famous centres of learning and pilgrimage until the 11th century CE. This particular doctrine opened the doors for Tantric religion. Both Shilinga and the bodhisattva were worshipped for many centuries until the Buddhist temple was converted to a purely Saivite temple. According to the mythological sources, Pandavas stayed here during their exile in the Mahabharata period.It is said by the locals that whoever entered these caves never returned. The locals also say that these caves are so long that through it we can reach Kashi in the north.

Name: Shri Ananthapadmanabha Kudupu Temple
Description: This temple is situated in Kudupu village, which is 10 Kms away from Mangalore City, in the Mangalore-Moodabidri route. This temple is dedicated to Lord Anantha Padmanabha (another form of Lord Vishnu) and famous for serpent worship. Annual festival Shashti is a famous religious ceremony falls in December. Also Nagarapanchami, a worship of sacrificing the milk to Lord Naga is celebrated with great devotion. Main deity Lord Anantha Padmanabha in the main sanctum is faced towards west. Naga Bana (place of serpent deity) though situated in eastern portion of the temple it is also faced towards west. There are more than three hundred of Serpent Idols in this Naga Bana. Holy pond Bhadra Saraswathi Thirtha is situated left side of the temple. In front of the temple there is one small shrine dedicated to Sub-deity Jarandaya. Inside behind the main sanctum there lies Sub-deity Shree Devi and Lord Mahaganapathi in southern portion. A holy anthill situated inside the temple beside which there is a stone idol of Lord Subramanya and either side of the main sanctum there are stone idols dedicated to Jaya and Vijaya (statues of divine watchmen). Out side in front of the temple there lies one Valmika Mantapa either side of which there are Shrines of Ayyappan and Navagriha.

Name: Nagaramadi Waterfalls
Description: Unveiling the mystery of Nagaramadi Waterfalls proves to be a challenge. While its exact location points towards Uttara Kannada district, Karnataka, near the village of Chendia (possibly also called Chendia Falls), details remain scarce. Name: Vaddi Falls
Description: Nestled amidst the lush Western Ghats of Uttara Kannada, Karnataka, Vaddi Falls beckons nature enthusiasts with its seasonal grandeur. Accessible via the scenic yet challenging Vaddi Ghats on State Highway 143, the falls transform during the monsoon (June to September) into a cascading spectacle.  Unlike its more developed counterparts, Vaddi Falls offers a charmingly rustic experience.  Be prepared for a short hike and proper footwear, but the reward is a refreshing dip in the pool at the falls' base (during monsoon) and the chance to immerse yourself in the beauty of nature.  This seasonal gem caters to those seeking an off-the-beaten-path adventure.
Review 1: This waterfalls is located just beside the road and the Flow of water will be Minimum in Summer season.Better visit this place on the month of August/Septemb
Review 2: There are multiple streams you get on the way to vibhooti falls, they are far more better than this one, so you can avoid spending time here

Name: Gundiadka (Nagundi) Falls
Description: The Gundiadka Falls, also known as Nagundi Falls, doesn't boast a grand cascading spectacle. Located near Bengaluru, Karnataka, it's more like a series of gentle rapids flowing over small rocks. However, its charm lies in its simplicity. Perfect for a quick getaway, you can relax by the flowing water, enjoy a picnic with family, or even take a refreshing dip (be cautious of currents). While it might not be ideal for thrill-seekers, Gundiadka Falls offers a peaceful escape from the city buzz, making it a suitable destination for those seeking a serene natural experience.
Review 1: I had an incredible time visiting this waterfall! The natural beauty is simply breathtaking. The crystal-clear water cascading down the rocks was a sight to behold. I highly recommend a visit to this stunning waterfall if you're in the area. It's an experience you won't forget!

Name: Kudroli Sri Gokarnanatheshwara Kshetra
Description: The Gokarnanatheshwara Temple, otherwise known as Kudroli Sri Gokarnanatha Kshetra, is in the Kudroli area of Mangalore in Karnataka, India. It was consecrated by Narayana Guru. It is dedicated to Gokarnanatha, a form of Lord Shiva. This temple was built in 1912 by Adhyaksha HoigeBazar Koragappa. This temple is now accepted as "Aadi" by the Billava community. The temple is 2 km from the centre of Mangalore city. The temple has Gopuram (tower like structure) decorated with murals of various gods and goddesses. Murals depict scenes from Hindu epics and legends.
Review 1: The temple is one of the best in India in southern architecture , looks gold covered. Easy access in the morning or in the evening, no crowd.
Review 2: The best thing about this place is it is clean and huge, and at least, on a Friday night, it was not crowded. This is very much a touristy place, with fake animals, small fenced-off gardens, bright lighting - and not necessarily an historical place to visit. Depends on what you prefer.

Traditional Aarti in the evening. If you want to enjoy the beauty of the temple do visit at night time. One can have full lighting effects. A decent parking space is available outside of temple. Great experience & devine feeling a must visit temple if you are in Mangalore. We visited this temple on 3rd Feb.2017 with family & feel relaxed in the temple's calmness atomsphere. The big & best temple of Mangalore city

Name: Paajaka Kshetra
Description: Pajaka Kshetra is the birthplace of a renowned philosopher, Shree Madhavacharya. The place is believed to be highly sacred and has been mentioned in a biographical poem named Sampraday Paddhati written by Shree Hrushikesha, a disciple of Shree Madhavacharya. Several facts and monuments associated with Madhavacharya have been maintained in the kshetra that devotees and tourists can explore.
Review 1: Beautiful and historical place. Sri Madhvacharya Guruji' s birth place. The home where Acharya lived has been preserved very well. The place has several interesting points which depicts the incidences in the life of the Sri Madhvacharya. Worth visiting the place. Nearby there are several holy ponds and temples. One can visit these places also.
Review 2: Must visit if you are a follower of Madhvacharya. Place where acharya was born and grew up.
Review 3: Very peaceful place. One has to visit this place on their trip to Udupi, the birth place of 'Sri Madhawcharyaru'.

Name: Jomlu Teertha
Description: At a distance of 32 km from Agumbe and 35 km from Udupi, Jomlu Theertha Falls is a mesmerizing waterfall situated at Handikallu village near Agumbe. It is one of the breathtaking waterfalls in Karnataka and among the best places to visit in Agumbe as part of the Agumbe Tour. Located in the Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary, Jomlu Theertha is small waterfall cascades down a rocky terrain from a height of 20 feet in the middle of the dense natural reserve. It is the second waterfall created by the River Sita, the first one being the Koodlu Theertha Falls. The gushing sound of the waterfall, the chirping of birds, and the calm atmosphere add to the charm of the falls. The place is perfect for weekend getaways with family and friends. The beautiful waterfall is ideal for taking a bath in its refreshing water. However, caution must be exercised by visitors during the monsoon season as the currents are very strong here. In fact, it is better not to enter the water during the rainy season as there have been several instances where people have lost their lives due to drowning in the water of the Jomlu Theertha Falls. For those who want to enjoy a bath in the water of the falls, it is advisable to visit the place after the monsoon season. It is advisable to carry food and water while on a trip to visit the waterfall as there are no shops near the falls. Visitors can carry fishing rods and try their hands at fishing in the water of the river.
Address: FWHF+7HF, Jomlu Falls Rd, Nalkur, Karnataka 576234

Name: Ramasamudra Lake
Description: Ramasamundra Lake is a favourite picnic spot among locals and travellers. It is believed to be created during last quarter of 14th century. The pond is said to have healing properties and is believed to have never gone dry. The pond was said to be created in the memory of Ramanatha, the son of King Veera Bhairava and brother of Veerapandya.

Name: Anekere Lake
Description:
The Anekere Alke was built in 1262 as a tank by Raja Pandyadeva. He belonged to the Bhairasa dynasty. The primary purpose of this tank was to serve as a bathing spot for the royal elephants. According to government records, it was initially spread over 25 acres. Later, it was used to supply the region with drinking water.

For over 8 centuries, the Anekere lake was the primary source of potable water for the city. In 1545 AD, one of the successors of Raja Pandyadeva, Pandya VI, commissioned the construction of the Kere Basadi in the middle of the lake.

Beautiful Mahaveer Jain temple in the centre of the pond. Newly reconstructed after almost 500 years.
Very neat and divine. Must visit
Review 2:
Certainly one of the most peaceful places to be around in the entire Mangalore region.
I've been here twice and loved my time here; it's a wonderful destination to be around at if you're travelling solo. I had absolutely no difficulties navigating through the place even with my lack of proficiency at Kannada; people were so helpful and kind.

Name: Oyster Rock Lighthouse
Description:
Oyster Rocks are a group of rocks on Devgad Island around 11 km from Karwar in Karnataka. Devgad is the highest rock formation of the same which is also home to the magnificent lighthouse. Also known as Devgad Island Lighthouse, Oyster Rock Lighthouse is the prime attraction on the island of Devgad. Constructed in the 1860s by the British, this lighthouse became functional from 25 March 1864.

Boasting of stunning colonial architecture, the towering lighthouse has a dome crowning it through which the tourists can see the entrance to the lantern room. It is a perfect place to watch the sunrise and sunset moments. Besides, the top of the tower offers enchanting panoramic vistas and the view of the city below. In addition to that, you can also try sports adventure activities like scuba diving and snorkelling at the site. Oyster Island can be reached in machine boats from the Karwar Port.

Name: Anashi Waterfall
Description: A paradise for nature lovers, Anashi Waterfall is a splendid attraction near Anshi Village. The enchanting fall is located amidst dense forestation, very close to SH 34 and serves as a pleasant pit stop for travellers or commuters passing by. The water body also attracts several birds and animals thriving in the green zone that one can spot while exploring the attraction.

Name: Narahari Hill
Description: Nestled in Dakshina Kannada district, Karnataka, Narahari Hill beckons with its spiritual significance and scenic beauty. Roughly 28 kilometers away from Mangalore, the hill is most renowned for the Sri Sadashiva Temple, a revered pilgrimage site for Hindus.  Legend links Narahari Hill to the Pandavas, heroes of the epic Mahabharata.  Reaching the temple perched atop the hill requires climbing around 333 steps, a moderately challenging feat rewarded by breathtaking panoramic views.  The temple complex itself holds another unique feature - four Teertha Koopas, holy ponds shaped like a Shankha, Chakra, Gadha, and Padma.  Beyond its religious significance, Narahari Hill is a haven for nature lovers, offering stunning vistas of the surrounding landscapes.  Remember to wear proper footwear for the climb, and if you're planning a visit, aim for the winter or summer months to avoid navigating slippery trails during the monsoon.
Review 1: Beautiful view point. Best scenic place to visit. Vehicle entry to top is little tricky but good drivers can. Better is to take steps if driving at a deep inclination is a problem. Calm and peaceful to spend a quality time.

Better to park at bottom and climb by stairs. From Mangalore it took nearly 1 hour by car. The sunset from the top of hill is just awesome. You can see mountains all around from the top. It was lush greenery during rainy season. Not crowded. Washrooms are available on the top of hill. Some historical connection with Mahabharata is there with the hill. Caretaker will guide and explain everything. No fee to visit the place. It is a religious place basically. From main road it is just 200 mts inside. Google map location is correct.

Name: Sri Karinjeshwara Temple
Description: The Sri Karinjeshwara Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in Karinja, Bantwal Taluk, Kavalamudur Village, Dakshina Kannada district, Karnataka, India.  The temple is perched on the peak of Karinja Hill, offering panoramic views of the surrounding area.  It's estimated to be over 1,000 years old, making it a significant historical and cultural landmark .History and Significance: The temple's rich history is said to date back to various mythological eras. It was known as 'Roudra Giri' during Krutha Yuga, 'Bhima Shaila' in Dwapara Yuga, 'Gajendra Giri' in Tretha Yuga, and 'Karinja' in the present Kali Yuga. The temple is also believed to have connections to the Ramayana and Mahabharata epics
Review 1: Getting a dip in Gadha Thirtha during Ashada (Aati) is considered very auspicious! Must visit Sept..
Review 2: A peaceful temple with a great view. Best to visit early morning to avoid tiredness.Beware of monkeys!!
Review 3: Karinjeshwara temple is a relatively unknown one for non-locals. Located at a short distance from both Bantwal and Belthangady, it is a beautiful temple nestled in the Kodya hill ranges. With quite a bit of mythological connect, natural beauty of the ghats, natural caves, fascinating temples and some peaceful nagarabanas near the temples, it's a beautiful place to spend half a day. You can drive up half the way and take the 150 odd steps or take the steps all the way up. Timings of the shrine : 9am-12 pm and 6pm-7pm. The road to the temple itself is an experience (even if a short drive)

Name: Apsarakonda Waterfalls
Description: The Apsarakonda Waterfalls are a set of cascading waterfalls located in the Uttara Kannada district of Karnataka, India. The falls are named after Apsaras, celestial nymphs in Hindu mythology, who are said to have bathed in the pool below the falls. The Apsarakonda Waterfalls are a popular tourist destination, especially for those visiting the nearby town of Honnavar. The waterfalls are a short distance from the town and can be easily reached by car or motorbike. There are also steps leading down to the base of the falls, making them accessible to visitors of all ages.The Apsarakonda Waterfalls are particularly beautiful during the monsoon season, when the water levels are high. However, the falls are still worth visiting during the dry season, as the pool below the falls is a great place to cool off on a hot day.

Name: Sharavathi Kandla Mangrove Boardwalk
Description:
The Sharavathi Kandla Mangrove Boardwalk is a scenic nature trail located in the Honnavar region of Karnataka, India. It provides visitors with a unique opportunity to explore the lush mangrove forests bordering the Sharavathi River.  The well-maintained wooden walkway winds through the dense vegetation, offering close-up views of the fascinating ecosystem. 
Image of Sharavathi Kandla Mangrove Boardwalk, IndiaOpens in a new window The 1.5 kilometer long path leads visitors into the heart of the mangroves, where they can observe a variety of plant and animal life. The brackish waters surrounding the mangroves are a nursery for many fish species, while the trees themselves provide habitat for numerous birds, crabs, and insects. Informative signs are positioned along the boardwalk, educating visitors about the vital role that mangrove forests play in the environment.
Review 1: The Mangroves Boardwalk offers a unique opportunity to explore the diverse ecosystem of mangrove forests in a protected and accessible environment. Visitors can stroll along elevated wooden pathways that wind through the dense mangrove trees, providing an up-close look at the intricate root systems and diverse wildlife that call this habitat home. The boardwalk not only offers a chance to observe rare plant and animal species but also educates visitors about the importance of mangroves in coastal ecosystems. Whether it's birdwatching, photography, or simply enjoying a peaceful walk in nature, the Mangroves Boardwalk provides a memorable and educational experience for visitors of all ages.

Name: Basavaraj Durga Island
Description: Basavaraj Durga Island is an island in the Arabian Sea near Honnavar. It is part of Honnavar Taluk in Karnataka State of India. The island has a total area of 19 hectares and an elevation of 45 to 50m. There are a number of fresh water wells. The island can be reached by boat, fishing trawlers or canoe (although canoe is not recommended for visitors) by a sail upstream on river sharavati. The island lies 4km from Honnavar, 3km from Sharavati Bay and just 1km from Mavinakurve village (an island which also has a beach), [1] and 700 meters from Taribagilu village, another beach island. The trip takes about 30 to 45 Minutes from Honnavar and 5 to 10 Minutes from Taribagilu village by sail. The landing place is at the southeastern part of the island, where there is an architectural entrance made by stones which was also the entrance to fort. The top of the island is a plateau covered with dry grass and trees that can be seen only at the sloping part of the island.

Name: Bappanadu Durga Parameshwari Temple - Mulki
Description: Nestled in the Bappanadu village, roughly 28 kilometers from Mangalore, lies the colorful Bappanadu Durga Parameshwari Temple. This vibrant house of worship is dedicated to the Goddess Durga Parameshwari, but with a unique twist - the deity is worshipped in the form of a Linga, a symbolic representation of Lord Shiva. The temple's origin story is just as fascinating. Legend says a Muslim merchant named Bappa, encountering a divine vision during a storm on the Shambhavi River, was instructed to build this temple. The village's name itself, Bappanadu, reflects Bappa's contribution.  Celebrated for its annual Brahma Rathotsava festival in April and the enormous Bappanadu Dolu (drum), this temple offers a truly unique experience for visitors seeking a blend of serenity, history, and local legend.
Address: Bappanadu guthu, Bappanaadu Temple Road, Bappanaadu Temple Rd, Mulki, Karnataka 574154
Review 1: This colorful temple is situated in the town of Mulki about 30 kms from Udupi. Being away from the beaten track, the crowd is less here and the darshan is relatively much faster. Even for those who want to perform pooja it is not an effort and you can be on your way pretty soon. There are sufficient sheltered places to sit and relax or meditate. The area is clean and well maintained. The visit was one of satisfaction. The place is well connected by regular bus service to Udupi in addition to taxis.

Outside the temple there is a man with light chats/snacks which was very tasty. Do try once.

Name: Hire Basadi - Neminatha Swami Digambara
Description: A roughly 250 kilometer drive from Bengaluru awaits you if you seek the architectural wonder of Hire Basadi, a Jain temple in Karkala, Karnataka. Renowned for its exquisite blend of Jain and Hindu styles, the temple is a prominent pilgrimage site for Jains and a captivating destination for any visitor.  Intricate carvings and woodwork adorn the structure, while the central sanctum houses a revered idol of Lord Neminatha, the 22nd Jain Tirthankara. Hire Basadi boasts a unique feature - an underground chamber believed to be a meditative retreat for Jain saints and a repository for sacred relics.

Name: Arisina Gundi Falls
Description: Nestled deep within the Mookambika Wildlife Sanctuary, Arisina Gundi Falls, also known as Arasina Makki Falls, is a hidden gem near Agumbe. Reaching this cascading beauty requires a moderately challenging trek of over 2 kilometers, but the reward is a truly breathtaking sight.  Since the falls reside inside a protected area, securing permission from the local forest department is mandatory before embarking on your adventure.  The ideal time to visit Arisina Gundi Falls falls within the winter and summer seasons, allowing you to navigate the trails comfortably and enjoy the refreshing waters.  However, be prepared to encounter leeches in this lush environment.  With proper precautions and a sense of adventure, Arisina Gundi Falls promises an unforgettable experience.

It comes under the restricted area of the sanctuary. Travellers have to seek special permission from the local forest department authorities for visiting this waterfall. Both summer and winter seasons are ideal months for visiting this waterfall.

Name: Barkana falls
Description: The Barkana Falls are located between Agumbe and Shimoga and derive their name from ‘Barka’, the mouse deer, a shy creature that inhabits this particular region. The trek route runs through the dense rainforests of the Western Ghats. During monsoons, the regions start buzzing with life as new streams begin to emerge and the canopy of vegetation gets dense enough for any traveller to lose orientation. The best time to visit these falls are in the early days of winter.

Beautiful place. It is 6km trek from malandur near agumbe on way to Narasimha Parvatha. We got to trek through diverse and thick rainforest of the western ghats. We directly reach the falls where it takes a dip of 600ft. All together wonderful experience of trek and nature beauty.
To get to this place have to take entry ticket from forest check post in malandur village.

Name: Camp 21
Description: Camp 21 is a fantastic Beach Getaway in the Picturesque Someshwara-Uchila Village of Mangalore, a quick 20 Mins. The Beach Serviced homes are located in a quaint little town of Someshwara that carries with it an idyllic charm with its swaying Palms, Casuarinas groves & the backwaters of the Mangrove estuary. The region has some of the finest beach stretches along the western coast.
