Name: RiverRoost Resorts
Description: Luxury riverside Resort in Mangalore, Karnataka. On the banks of Gurpura river, it makes a perfect getaway to relax & rejuvenate. We offer you a blend of village life with the luxuries of modern living. Guests can choose from Wood Cabins and dorms to Luxury Rooms. The resort has an outdoor Swimming Pool, a Conference room, mini gym, children's recreational area and many onsite activities. About 15 kms away from Mangalore city, the resort is set amidst coconut and areca plantations. Also near us is Pilikula Nisargadhama, an eco-educational and tourism park and the Pilikula Golf Club. Come enjoy our hospitality! And views that need no filter!

Name: Sattva Camps and Cottages
Description: Sattva Camps and Cottages is an accommodation option located in Malpe, Karnataka, India. There is not much descriptive information available online about the property, but based on its name, it can be inferred that it offers a combination of camping and cottage-style stays. This could be a good option for travelers who want to experience the outdoors but also appreciate the comfort of a private room. Malpe is a beautiful coastal town known for its beaches, fishing, and water sports. Staying at Sattva Camps and Cottages would allow you to be close to all of these activities.  Since it is located in Karnataka, you can also expect South Indian cuisine to be available nearby.

Name: Trophical beach villa and camping
Description: Tropical Bay in Malpe could be the perfect destination for you, offering both beachside camping and a luxurious villa. Featuring a private beach area, Tropical Bay allows you to enjoy the tranquility of the Malpe coast right at your doorstep.  In the comfort of your villa, you can indulge in delicious in-room breakfast or fire up the barbecue for a beachside cookout. While detailed information regarding Tropical Bay is limited online, contacting the property directly through booking websites should provide a clearer picture of their offerings.  For a more rustic experience, consider His Grace Camping near Malpe Beach, which offers basic amenities but might not include private rooms.

Name: Seethanadi Nature Camp
Description: Located 40 km from Udupi, the Seethanadi Nature Camp in Hebri is certainly an escape from the maddening rush of daily life. Amidst refreshing greenery, this lovely camp takes you away from the furore of cities. Besides setting out on nature walks and admiring the marvels of nature, the camp organizes a number of activities for its guests. Head here for a hassle free vacation. This Nature camp is situated inside Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary. This Sanctuary protects the last remaining low elevation rain forests in entire Western Ghats.

Name: TentMonk Beach Stay & Resort Mangalore
Description: TentMonk Beach Stay & Resort Mangalore offers a unique blend of affordability and relaxation by the beach. Located near Ullal in Mangalore, it's not right in the city center, but that translates to a quieter stay.  While the name might suggest tents, TentMonk Beach Stay & Resort actually offers cottages, making it a good option for those who enjoy the beach atmosphere but prefer a bit more comfort than traditional camping.  Reviews praise the property for its friendly staff, on-site restaurant with a dinner buffet, and even a game room for some indoor fun. If you're looking for a laid-back beach getaway at a reasonable price, TentMonk Beach Stay & Resort could be a strong contender.
Address: Tentmonk, near uchila Beach end point, ullal, Mangaluru, Karnataka 575023

Name: Bhagavathi Nature Camp
Description: Nestled within the verdant embrace of Kudremukh National Park in Karnataka, Bhagavathi Nature Camp offers an idyllic escape for nature enthusiasts. This eco-friendly camp, situated near the banks of the Bhadra River, serves as a launchpad for exploring the park's rich biodiversity.  Trekkers can embark on various trails, while birdwatchers can delight in the symphony of avian calls echoing through the dense forests. The camp itself provides comfortable accommodation in tents or cottages, all thoughtfully furnished and well-maintained.  After a day of adventure, unwind under a blanket of stars by a crackling bonfire or relax in the watchtower, taking in the breathtaking views of the surrounding hills. With its focus on nature immersion and sustainable practices, Bhagavathi Nature Camp promises an unforgettable experience for those seeking a true connection with the wild.

Name: Mundgod Tibetan Camp
Description: Immerse yourself in a unique cultural experience at the Doeguling Tibetan Settlement, also known as the Mundgod Tibetan Camp, located in Teginkoppa, Karnataka. Established in 1966, this vibrant community houses Tibetan refugees who have preserved their rich heritage in exile.  Explore the bustling marketplace filled with colorful prayer flags and traditional handicrafts.  Wander through the magnificent Ganden Jangchub Chöling Monastery, the second largest Tibetan settlement in India, and be captivated by its intricate architecture and serene atmosphere.  Learn about Tibetan Buddhism through cultural shows and interact with the welcoming locals who are happy to share their stories.  More than just a refugee camp, Mundgod Tibetan Camp offers a glimpse into a resilient culture and a chance to experience the spirit of Tibet amidst the scenic landscapes of Karnataka.
Address: X2R2+HQ5, Lama Camp 1, Mundgod, Teginkoppa, Karnataka 581349

Name: Trek and Stay
Description: Nestled between the Western Ghats and the Arabian Sea, Kundapura is a treasure trove for adventure seekers and beach lovers alike. Image of Kundapura Karnataka beachOpens in a new window For the trekker in you, Kundapura serves as a gateway to the magnificent Kodachadri Hills. Lush greenery, cascading waterfalls, and breathtaking viewpoints await those who embark on this thrilling trek.  After conquering the trails, you can rest and recharge at cozy guesthouses or homestays located at the base of the hills. Kundapura also boasts pristine beaches like Kodi Beach, Maravanthe Beach, and Malpe Beach, each offering a slice of paradise. Imagine waking up to the gentle rhythm of waves, spending your days soaking up the sun on the golden sands, and indulging in fresh seafood delicacies. Numerous beach resorts and homestays cater to every taste and budget,  making your post-trek relaxation truly blissful.

Name: Lion Tailed Macaque Eco Park
Description: Venture into the lush forests of Hanehalli, Karnataka, and discover the Lion-Tailed Macaque Eco Park. Established with the purpose of conserving the endangered Lion-Tailed Macaque monkey, this park offers a unique opportunity to observe these primates in their natural habitat.  These playful creatures, known for their distinctive mane of hair around their face, are a fascinating sight to behold. The park provides walking trails that meander through the forest canopy, allowing visitors a glimpse into the lives of these monkeys.

Name: Stella Mary’s Church
Description: Beyond its role in conservation, the Lion-Tailed Macaque Eco Park also serves as an educational center.  Informational boards and guided tours (if available) shed light on the importance of protecting these endangered animals and their habitat.  If you're looking for a responsible eco-tourism destination that combines nature observation with education, the Lion-Tailed Macaque Eco Park is a worthwhile addition to your Karnataka itinerary.

Name: Our Lady of Fatima Church, Perampalli
Description: Our Lady of Fatima Church, Perampally is situated in Udupi district, a coastal district of Karnataka State. Surrounded by lush greenery, the Church is about 4 kilometres away from the District headquarters and seven kilometres away from the main city of Udupi. Parishioners of the Church at Perampally are basically agriculturists. Since cultivation and agricultural products are  the main source of their livelihood. Prior to becoming an independent Parish in the year 1958, Perampally was a part of Milagres Church, Kallianpur and later that of Kolalgiri Church jurisdictionally. The Catholic faithful living in and around Perampally had to take a lot of trouble to reach the Parish Church for their spiritual needs and to fulfil their obligations. During the rainy season the situation was bad because the low-lying area around used to get flooded thereby making the people quite difficult to get out of their houses. Under normal circumstances, they had to cross a river to reach the church. The threat or danger of getting drowned in the river was always there.
Address: 9Q89+PMH, Perampalli Nekkar Krishnadasa Marga, Udupi, Karnataka 576102

Name: Mother of Sorrows Church
Description: Steeped in religious history, Mother of Sorrows Church in Kapu, Karnataka awaits further exploration. Dedicated to the Virgin Mary under her sorrowful aspect, the church likely features poignant imagery depicting Mary's grief over Jesus's suffering. Given Karnataka's Catholic population, the church itself is probably Catholic.  However, specific details about its architectural style, history, and cultural significance within Kapu remain elusive online.  To delve deeper, consider contacting the church directly or reaching out to the local diocese for insights.
Address: Mother of Sorrow's Church, Kapu, Brahmagiri, Udupi, Karnataka 576101

Name: Milagres Catholic Cathedral, Kallianpur (Udupi Diocese)
Description: The Milagres Catholic Cathedral, also known as the Cathedral of Our Lady of Miracles, stands as a landmark in Kallianpur, Karnataka, not far from the coastal town of Malpe.  This impressive structure boasts a rich history, dating back to the 17th century when it was first established by Portuguese missionaries.  Originally a church, it was elevated to the status of a cathedral in 1995.  The Milagres Cathedral is known for its beautiful Indo-Portuguese architecture, a unique blend of European and Indian styles.  While details are scarce online, one can expect to find intricate carvings and possibly murals adorning the interior.  Dedicated to Our Lady of Miracles, the cathedral is a revered pilgrimage site for Catholics in the region.  If you're looking for a place steeped in history, cultural heritage, and religious significance, the Milagres Catholic Cathedral is definitely worth a visit during your trip to Malpe.
Address: 9PWM+MJ8, Post, behind Milagres College, Kalayanapura, Karnataka 576114

Name: St. Sebastian Church Mangaluru
Description: Since Karnataka has a large Catholic population and the church is named after a saint, St. Sebastian Church is likely a Catholic denomination. The church's dedication is to Saint Sebastian, a Roman soldier martyred in the 3rd century for his Christian faith.  If you're visiting Mangaluru and interested in learning more about St. Sebastian Church, reaching out to the church itself, searching for local historical accounts, or contacting the local diocese or parish are all good options to glean a deeper understanding of this place of worship.

Name: Infant Jesus Shrine
Description: The Infant Jesus Shrine in Bikarnakatte, Mangaluru, is a popular Catholic pilgrimage destination dedicated to the childhood of Jesus Christ. Built in 1996 by the Carmelite priests, the shrine has grown from a place of quiet devotion to a vibrant center of faith.  Every Thursday, devotees gather for prayers and celebrations, but the annual feast in January, which includes a nine-day novena, is the major draw, attracting thousands from across the region.  The shrine itself is known for its peaceful atmosphere and miraculous blessings received by those who pray there.  It serves as a beacon of hope and a symbol of Jesus's enduring love for all.
Address: House No. # 3-13-1246, Carmel Hill, St. Joseph’s Monastery, Kulshekar Post, Mangaluru, Karnataka 575005

Name: Holy Cross Church
Description: The holy cross is the central symbol of Jesus's crucifixion and Christianity, suggesting this is a Catholic church. Holy Cross Church's size and location within Mangaluru are unknown. It could be a historical landmark, standing as a testament to the city's Catholic heritage, or a more contemporary house of worship serving the local community.
Address: Kulshekar Church Rd, Kulashekara, Mangaluru, Karnataka 575005

Name: St. Lawrence Church, Bondel
Description: St Lawrence Church, Bondel is one of the parishes of the Diocese of Mangalore. It is situated 8 kms away from the Heart of the City on the way to Bajpe Airport. It is a very beautiful place surrounded by Pacchanady, Moodushedde, Marakada, Kavoor and Padavinangadi villages. This parish was established on April 10 in the year 1923. Though it began like a mustard seed with few families today it is serving nearly 1000 families, having 27 wards. This Parish has received the service of 10 parish priests, more than 23 Assistant priests who were able and dynamic. Under their leadership the parish has grown in all the capacities.
Address: WV89+VJG, Airport Rd, Bondel, Mangaluru, Karnataka 575008

Name: Ballalarayana Durga Fort
Description: Forts always have a mysterious aura surrounding them. Most of them are reminiscences of a rich bygone era. Every fort has a history associated with it. Now if a fort exists in the midst of dense forest and atop a hill in the beautiful Western Ghats, it is bound to be a place full of history and mystery. Ballalarayana Durga fort in the Chikmagalur district of Karnataka is one such amazing fort. This isolated fort can only be reached by trekking through the hilly forest region. It is situated in Bettabalige that stands in the midst of Chikmagalur’s Kottegehara village and the Kalasa temple-town. It is one of the few forts that can be found in the Western Ghats.

Name: Sadashivagada Fort
Description: Nestled amidst the lush greenery of Uttara Kannada district in Karnataka, Sadashivagada Fort stands as a testament to a bygone era.  While its exact construction date is undetermined, historical records suggest it was built sometime in the 16th or 17th century.  The fort's strategic location overlooking the Arabian Sea and the strategically important Sharavathi River made it a vital defensive outpost for the ruling dynasties of the time.  The fort itself is believed to have been constructed using laterite stones and may have once housed a garrison of soldiers.  Today, the ruins of Sadashivagada Fort offer a glimpse into the region's military history and provide a scenic spot for exploration.  Be aware that the fort might be in a deteriorated state, so proper footwear and caution are advised if you plan to visit.

Name: Bankapur fort
Description: Rising majestically in the town of Bankapura, Karnataka, Bankapur Fort is a captivating historical landmark.  While the exact date of construction is undetermined, estimates place it around the 16th or 17th century.  The fort's imposing structure, built with massive granite stones, served as a crucial defense point for the ruling dynasties of the era.  Encompassing a substantial area, the fort likely housed soldiers, storehouses, and other essential buildings needed to sustain a garrison.  Today, the fort stands as a silent sentinel to the region's past.  Visitors can explore the ramparts, gateways, and ruins within the fort complex, offering a glimpse into a bygone era.  It's important to note that due to its age, the fort might be in a state of disrepair.  Proper footwear and caution are recommended if you plan to visit Bankapur Fort.

Name: Devgad Island
Description: Off the coast of Karwar, Karnataka, lies Devgad Island, a cluster of islets also known as Oyster Rock Island. The crown jewel of this island group is Devgad, a rocky summit topped by the historic Oyster Rock Lighthouse, built in the 1860s.  The surrounding waters boast a vibrant tapestry of coral reefs and marine life, making Devgad Island a potential hotspot for scuba diving and snorkeling.  The Karnataka government is actively developing Devgad Island as the state's second scuba diving hub, alongside Netrani Island. This, coupled with the island's natural beauty and serene atmosphere, positions Devgad Island as an exciting future destination for adventure seekers and nature lovers.  However, information regarding public access and amenities remains limited at present, so staying updated on developments is key before planning a trip.

Name: Parshvanatha Swamy Basadi, Venoor
Description: This temple is situated behind the fort enclosure of the Baahubali idol. It has Loha Pancha Loha – (5 Lohas) idol of Parshwanath as the main deity. The renovation of this basadi was done in 1936 by His Holiness Swasti Shri Records indicate that Charukeerthi Bhattaraka was conducted by Swamiji Moodbidri, a Jain monastery.

Name: Shri Neminaatha Swami Basadi
Description: At a distance of 37 Kms from Udupi & 50 Kms from Mangalore, Neminath Basadi is a Jain temple constructed in 1329. It is located very close to Bahubali Betta / Gomatheshwara Statue (about 0.5 Km). The presiding deity of this temple is Mulnayak Bhagvan Neminath. There is a 54 feet Manasthambha, carved out of single rock, which is installed in front of the Basadi. The complex also houses Lord Mahavir, Chandranath Swamy, Adinath Swamy, Ananthanath and Padmavathi basadis, and the Bhujabali Brahmacharya Ashram. Chaturmukha Basadi (1 Km), Gomatheshwara Statue (0.5 Kms) and Ramasamudra Lake (1 Km) are nearby attractions.

Name: Shri Jwalamalini Devi Atishaya Kshetra Simhanagadde Digambar Jain Mandir
Description: Shri Jwalamalini Devi Atishaya Kshetra Simhanagadde Digambar Jain Mandir, also known as Simhanagadde Jain Temple, is a revered Jain pilgrimage site located in Narasimharajapura, Karnataka, India. Enshrined within the temple complex is the sacred idol of Jwalamalini Devi, the Yakshini (divine attendant) of Bhagwan Chandraprabhu, the eighth Tirthankara in Jainism. The temple's origins can be traced back to the 15th century, and its construction is attributed to the queen of the Ger-soppa Soduv Empire. The temple's name, Simhanagadde, translates to "Lion's Hill," derived from the presence of a hillock resembling a lion's shape in the vicinity. The main temple, dedicated to Jwalamalini Devi, is an architectural marvel, showcasing intricate carvings and sculptures depicting Jain iconography. The temple's inner sanctum houses the idol of Jwalamalini Devi, adorned with jewels and radiating divine energy. Devotees flock to the temple to seek blessings, perform puja rituals, and experience the spiritual ambiance.

Name: Kundadri Shri Parshwanatha Basadi
Description: Perched amidst the scenic Western Ghats in Karnataka, the Kundadri Shri Parshwanatha Basadi is a Jain temple revered for its history and spiritual significance.  Believed to be built in the 17th century, the Basadi is dedicated to Lord Parshwanatha, the 23rd Jain Tirthankara.  The presence of a footprint shrine attributed to the revered Jain scholar Acharya Kundakunda adds to the temple's historical weight.  The main attraction is the 3.5-foot statue of Bhagwan Parshwanatha, which is bathed in sunlight on Makara Sankranti, creating a mesmerizing spectacle.  While specific architectural details are unavailable, Jain temples are known for intricate craftsmanship, suggesting the Basadi is likely adorned with beautiful carvings.  Natural ponds and a sacred spring add to the serenity of the place.  The Kundadri Shri Parshwanatha Basadi serves as a pilgrimage site for Jains, attracting devotees seeking peace, prayer, and spiritual connection.

Name: Nalluru Shri Digambara Jaina Basadi
Description: Tucked away in Nallur, Karnataka, lies the Nalluru Shri Digambara Jaina Basadi.  While specific details about this temple are elusive online, its name offers some clues.  "Digambara" suggests the temple belongs to the Digambara sect of Jainism, one of the two main Jain denominations. The enshrined deity is likely one of the many revered figures in Jainism, with Parshwanatha, the 23rd Tirthankara, being a common possibility.  Furthermore, Nallur itself has a rich Jain heritage, hinting that the temple might be part of a larger Jain community or hold historical significance within the region.  If you're curious to delve deeper into the Nalluru Shri Digambara Jaina Basadi's history and significance, searching for local news articles, travel blogs, or reaching out to the Jain community in Nallur could be your best course of action.

Name: Manipal Lake
Description: Nestled amidst the academic buzz of Manipal town lies Manipal Lake, also known as Manna Palla Lake.  This freshwater lake, spanning over 60 acres, serves as a hub for recreation and leisure.  Walking trails circling the lake are popular with joggers, walkers, and picnickers seeking a breath of fresh air. The lake's water levels fluctuate throughout the year, brimming during monsoons and receding in summer.  For some aquatic fun, paddle boats, row boats, and even water scooters can be rented to explore the lake. Birdwatchers can rejoice in the diverse birdlife that frequents the area, while the serene atmosphere provides a welcome escape from the town's energy.  A visit to Manipal Lake can be further enriched by exploring the Prasanna Ganapati Temple situated on its banks, a popular spot for prayer and offerings.  Whether you seek outdoor activities or a tranquil escape, Manipal Lake offers a charming experience for visitors.

Name: Unkal Lake
Description: About 110 years old, the lake covers an area of nearly 200 acres. This site is renowned as the 'Karma Bhoomi' of Shri Siddappajja, who was born in 1859. He eloped from his home at the age of 14 to find a Guru and resided in Unkal Mailarlings Temple.

Name: Pilikula Lake Garden
Description: Pilikula Lake Garden! Nestled within the Pilikula Nisargadhama eco-park, this 5-acre lake serves as a scenic centerpiece. Verdant lawns bordering the water create pockets of relaxation, with dedicated rest areas and drinking water facilities for visitor comfort. For a leisurely exploration of the lake, hop on a pedal boat and soak in the picturesque surroundings. The gardens surrounding the lake are a visual treat, boasting beautiful landscaping that's perfect for a family picnic or a romantic stroll. Whether you crave a quiet moment with nature or a fun day out, Pilikula Lake Garden offers a charming escape within the heart of the city.

Name: Gadha Theertha
Description: Shrouded in local tradition, Gadha Theertha in Bantwal, Karnataka remains somewhat enigmatic online.  The name itself offers clues, with "Gadha" translating to "pit" or "trench" in Sanskrit and "Theertha" meaning "sacred water body."  This suggests a pit or well known for its holy water, possibly linked to Hinduism or Jainism given Bantwal's rich history in these religions.  Gadha Theertha could be a revered natural spring with holy water used for rituals or bathing, or it might be a temple tank associated with a local Jain or Hindu temple complex.  To unravel the mystery of Gadha Theertha, delving into local news articles, historical accounts, or even academic publications on Bantwal's religious sites might prove fruitful.  Alternatively, reaching out to local priests, Jain monks, or knowledgeable residents of Bantwal could shed light on the history and significance of this intriguing place.

Name: Dabbe Falls
Description: Nestled within the lush embrace of the Western Ghats in Karnataka, Dabbe Falls tumbles down a majestic 110 meters in three cascading steps.  "Dabbe," meaning "steps" in Kannada, perfectly captures the essence of this waterfall where the water seems to descend in a rhythmic dance over natural rock formations.  Located near Sagar town in Shimoga district, Dabbe Falls is part of the pristine Sharavathi Wildlife Sanctuary, teeming with diverse flora and fauna.  Unlike its more crowded counterparts, Dabbe Falls offers an untouched beauty, ideal for nature enthusiasts seeking a serene escape.  Reaching the falls involves a moderate to challenging trek through the dense forest, adding a touch of adventure to the experience.  The monsoon season (June to September) transforms Dabbe Falls into a spectacular sight, with water cascading down in full force.  Keep your eyes peeled during your trek, as you might encounter some of the park's wildlife, from monkeys and hornbills to the occasional deer.

Name: Kanuru Fort
Description: Also known as the Keladi Kote, this fort is located in Shimoga district and is named after the Keladi dynasty that ruled this place. Kote means fort in Kannada. Food and tents must be carried by all visitors on their way here. It is not directly accessible by road, one will have to walk a few minutes before reaching the fort. So it is best avoided by people with ailments and physical disabilities.

Name: Jog Falls
Description: The second-highest plunge waterfall in India, Jog Falls is a major tourist attraction in Karnataka and is the highest waterfall in the state. Second, to the Nohkalikai Falls of Meghalaya, Jog falls drops about a huge 253 m (850 ft. ) in a single fall. However, due to the construction of Linganamakki Dam which is a hydroelectricity plant closeby, the flow in the falls is hugely restricted before monsoons. So, it is best to go during the Monsoon season to see the falls in its full form. Jog Falls is a 2 hours drive from the main Shimoga city. Also known as Gerosappa Falls or the Joga Falls, this seasonal waterfall is broken into four segments - Raja, Roarer, Rocket and Rani. They're named based on certain characteristics of the streams. Raja is an unbroken stream, Roarer is a strong and violent current that gushes down to meet the Raja stream, Rocket flows down in different jets and Rani is a quiet stream with falls in foam.

Name: Talasi Waterfalls
Description: Tucked away amidst the verdant Western Ghats in Karnataka lies Talasi Falls, a hidden gem shrouded in tropical beauty.  This cascading waterfall isn't for the faint of heart when it comes to accessibility.  Located between Mastikatte and Thirthahalli in the Malnad region, reaching Talasi Falls requires a bit of an adventure.  After hitting Yadur on the main road, you'll need to turn inward and follow the signs (if you can find them) for a few kilometers before reaching a small parking spot.  From there, the final two kilometers are best conquered on foot, navigating a path through the dense forest. But for those willing to embrace the challenge, the reward is a magnificent waterfall cascading down a rocky outcrop. The monsoon season witnesses Talasi Falls at its most impressive, with forceful water flow and lush green surroundings.  However, the falls are still worth a visit even after the monsoons, offering a refreshing and secluded escape.  Be aware that information online about Talasi Falls is limited, including details on amenities or facilities.  So, coming prepared with essentials and respecting the natural environment are crucial for a safe and enjoyable experience.  Overall, Talasi Falls beckons the adventurous soul, promising a hidden paradise for those who don't mind going the extra mile.

Name: Onake Abbi Falls
Description: The Onake Abbi falls is one of the many waterfalls in Shimoga. The trek to the top of the fall is relatively short covering a distance of about 4-5 kilometres. The trail runs through a dense forest that is rich in flora and fauna. The summit of the trek offers a breathtaking view of the entire waterfall as it cascades from a height of 500 feet.

Name: Jogigundi Falls
Description:
Tucked away from the prying eyes of the world, the Jogigundi Falls are situated in the midst of the dense forests of Western Ghats. The unique feature of these falls is the point of origin. Unlike traditional waterfalls they do not fall from a height, instead they originate from a cave and run through a hill. The falls are not accessible by road and it requires a trek to reach the falls.

The trek route is not difficult and is an ideal destination for a half day visit. The place is made up of eroded rock and lush green forest and there is a natural pool of water at the end of the trek where you can swim and enjoy the bounties of Nature.
Address: F4P5+634, Jogi Gundi Entrance, Agumbe, Karnataka 577411

Name: Matthav Waterfalls Kabbinale
Description: Tucked away in the verdant foothills of the Western Ghats near Machattu Proper, Karnataka, lies Kabbinaale Falls. While details about this cascading wonder are elusive online, its name, translating to "sugarcane crushing unit" in Kannada, might hint at the area's past.  Situated amidst the dense forests characteristic of the Western Ghats, Kabbinaale Falls likely transforms into a powerful and scenic spectacle during the monsoon season (June to September).  Beyond the rainy months, the falls could still offer a refreshing escape into nature.  Reaching the falls might involve a trek through the forest, so be prepared for an adventure! If you're keen to learn more about Kabbinaale Falls, searching local news articles, travel blogs, or Karnataka's Forest Department might shed some light on accessibility and available facilities. With a bit of research and a sense of exploration, Kabbinaale Falls could be your hidden gem waiting to be discovered.

Name: Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary
Description: Nestled in the Western Ghats of Udupi, these semi-evergreen and evergreen forests have been named after the Lord Someshwera, whose temple lies in the sanctuary area. Receiving the highest rainfall in Karnataka, the Agumbe Ghat in Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary is known as the Cherrapunji of Karnataka. Potential sightings: Jackal, wild boar, spotted deer, gaur, wild dogs, monkeys, langurs, Hornills, squirrels, and macaques Waterfalls in the area: Jogi Gundi waterfalls, Onake Abbi Falls, Barkana Falls, and Koodlu Theertha Falls, among others.

Name: Narasimha Parvatha
Description: Towering over the foothills of the Western Ghats in Agumbe, Karnataka, Narasimha Parvatha, at 3,772 feet (1,150 meters), is the region's highest peak and a haven for trekkers.  The name itself translates to "embodiment of Lord Vishnu, Narasimha," and the trek offers stunning views as it winds through dense forests, hills, and valleys. There are two routes to the summit: a shorter and moderate one starting from Kigga village, and a longer and more challenging one from Mallandur village.  Hikers typically take 6-7 hours to reach the top, where they're rewarded with breathtaking panoramas. Part of the Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary within Kudremukh National Park, Narasimha Parvatha is ideal for adventurous nature lovers seeking tranquility.  However, due to the possibility of leeches on the trails, proper footwear and trekking poles are recommended.

Name: Sri Kalaseshwara Swaami Temple (Dakshina Kashi)
Description: Nestled amidst the picturesque Western Ghats in Karnataka, lies the Sri Kalaseshwara Swaami Temple, also revered as Dakshina Kashi.  This moniker translates to "southern Kashi," comparing its significance to the holy city of Varanasi in North India.  Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple attracts devotees seeking blessings and spiritual solace.  The surrounding hills and aroma of coffee and cardamom plantations create a serene atmosphere.  While specific details about the temple's architecture are limited, its status as Dakshina Kashi hints at its potential grandeur.  The Pancha Theertha, five sacred water bodies within the temple premises, add another layer of spiritual significance.  If you're looking for a pilgrimage site steeped in tradition and surrounded by natural beauty, Sri Kalaseshwara Swaami Temple (Dakshina Kashi) is a must-visit destination

Name: Kudremukha National Park
Description: Located amidst mountains, Kudremukh National Park is popular for its scenic beauty. Designated the status of a national park in the year 1987, the 600-kilometre square area is one of the most well preserved national parks in the state. The Kudremukh National Park is jewelled with natural beauty, high rising peaks studded with a plethora of flora and fauna to picturesque trekking routes overseeing verdant grasslands, there is much to experience here! The wildlife protected area is the second-largest belonging to a tropical wet evergreen forest in the zone of the Western Ghats. The area gains its name from the native language. Kudremukha translates to horse-face, referring to the highest mountain peak in the park which resembles the face of a horse from a particular side. It rises to a height of 1,894 meters (6,214 feet) and is the second highest peak in Karnataka. The area is the habitat of many endangered and endemic species of plants and animals, with mammals such as tigers, leopards and wild dogs as the primary predators of the region. Primarily developed as an important iron-ore mining town, conservationists successfully campaigned against the adverse mining effects on the environment. Kudremukh and its lush green surroundings are a nature and wildlife lover's paradise, serving you the best of Western Ghats in great detail.

Name: Kundadri Hill
Description: Enveloped by the lush embrace of the Western Ghats in Karnataka, Kundadri Hill rises 826 meters, beckoning both nature lovers and spiritual seekers.  The dense evergreen forests blanketing its slopes offer a refreshing escape, while the 17th-century Kundadri Shri Parshwanatha Basadi perched atop the hill satiates the soul.  This Jain temple, dedicated to Lord Parshwanatha, holds historical significance with a footprint shrine attributed to Acharya Kundakunda, a revered scholar.  Reaching the summit can be achieved through a scenic, 7-kilometer trek or a convenient drive on the newly built road.  For Jains, the intricate architecture of the Basadi and the serene atmosphere serve as a major pilgrimage destination.  Beyond its spiritual significance, Kundadri Hill's verdant beauty, with opportunities for birdwatching and simply embracing nature, makes it a perfect getaway for all.

Name: Murdeshwar Beach
Description: Lying along the periphery of the majestic Murudeshwar Temple is the beautiful beach by the same name. Overlooking the monumental statue of Lord Shiva, this beach is the perfect picnic spot for families and loved ones. The sand of this beach is quite excellent, and its silky texture is not very common. You can also enjoy boat rides around the magnificent Murudeshwar Temple. The Murudeshwar beach is a major tourist attraction in Karnataka. Surrounded by gentle hills and lush green foliage, this beach is always bustling with activity. The beauty of this place is enhanced by the coconut trees which are indigenous to this location. Early morning hours the best time to visit this place, when you might even find the company of flying seagulls and kingfisher birds. With its mighty sea waters splashing against the surface of the beach, the overall scenery of this destination is worthy of a visit.

Name: Magod Waterfalls
Description: Tucked away in Karnataka's Uttara Kannada district, Magod Falls tumbles down a majestic 200 meters in two stages.  Encased within the verdant embrace of the Western Ghats, the falls create a captivating scene with lush forests and the echoing roar of cascading water.  Magod Falls' charm lies in its natural beauty, best experienced during the monsoon season (June to September) when the water flow is at its most impressive.  Relatively uncrowded compared to other waterfalls, Magod Falls offers a peaceful escape.  Accessibility is easy, with a well-maintained walkway leading from the parking area to the viewing point, making it suitable for visitors of all ages.  If you're on the way, don't miss Kavade Kere, a beautiful lake just 6 kilometers from Yellapur, adding another layer to your Magod Falls adventure.  From refreshing dips in the monsoon to tranquil moments amidst nature, Magod Falls promises a captivating experience.
Address: RQX2+RM3, Magod falls Road, Magod, Karnataka 581359

Name: Anshi National Park
Description: Located at the eco-sensitive part of Western Ghats (altitude ranging from 200 meters to 900 meters) in Uttara Kannada district is Anshi National Park, an evergreen tropical rainforest. Anshi National Park is a part of the Dandeli Wildlife Sanctuary and covers about 500 square kilometres of the natural reserve.It is a famous Tiger Reserve and is now called the Kali Tiger Reserve. With high biodiversity that is most specific to the Western Ghats of India, the attraction is a favourite amongst nature and animal lovers. The park is home to hundreds of species of wild animals, endemic birds, herbs, shrubs, and reptiles. Overlooking the Kali river which flows through it, the remarkable topography of the park includes beautiful deep valleys, dense forests and narrow hills slopes.

Name: Nethravathi Peak
Description: Nestled amidst the majestic Western Ghats in Karnataka lies the Nethravathi Peak, a 1,520-meter tall gem for trekkers.  Named after the Netravathi River that originates nearby, this peak offers a moderately challenging trek with stunning rewards.  The path unfolds through verdant forests, cascading waterfalls, and open grasslands, culminating in breathtaking vistas of the surrounding hills and valleys.  The diverse flora and fauna, with possibilities of spotting everything from birds and monkeys to tigers and elephants, add to the adventure.  Beyond the scenic beauty, the peak holds spiritual significance for some locals, with a small temple perched at the summit.  Whether you're a seasoned trekker or a curious beginner, the Nethravathi Peak offers a captivating blend of nature, adventure, and potential spiritual connection, making it a perfect day trip from Bangalore or other nearby cities.  Just remember, the dry season (November to February) is the ideal time to conquer this peak, as the trails can get slippery during monsoons.  So lace up your boots, pack your essentials, and get ready to be awestruck by the beauty of the Nethravathi Peak!

Name: Katthale Basadi, Barkur
Description: Steeped in history and architectural intrigue, the Katthale Basadi in Barkur is an ancient Jain temple revered for its intricate craftsmanship.  Built by the Alupa rulers sometime between the 8th and 12th centuries AD, the Basadi stands out for its unique design.  Unlike most South Indian Dravidian temples, Katthale Basadi doesn't feature a towering gopuram, the ornate entrance structure.  Instead, the sanctum sanctorum is enclosed by stone walls and topped with sloping stone pillars.  While the original idol of Mahavira, the 23rd Jain Tirthankara, is no longer present, the Basadi's significance extends to the separate shrines dedicated to Shiva, Vishnu, and other Jain deities, reflecting the region's diverse religious heritage.  A visit to Katthale Basadi offers a glimpse into the architectural styles of a bygone era, along with a deeper understanding of Jainism and its peaceful philosophy.
Address: 3-22, Acharbettu road, near Garadi, Hosala Village, Barkurpete, Moodahadu, Karnataka 576210

Name: Mookambika Wildlife Sanctuary - Kodachadri
Description: The Mookambika Wildlife Sanctuary in Karnataka, named after the revered Kollur Mookambika Temple within its borders, is a protected paradise spanning over 370 square kilometers.  Nestled amidst the lush Western Ghats, the sanctuary shelters a diverse range of wildlife like tigers, leopards, and dholes, alongside a vibrant bird population.  Trekkers flock to Kodachadri Hill, a prominent peak within the sanctuary, for its challenging trails and breathtaking vistas.  From evergreen forests to dry grasslands, the sanctuary boasts a rich tapestry of flora and fauna, making it a treasure trove for nature enthusiasts seeking an unforgettable escape into the wild.

Name: Sharavati Backwater
Description: A serene escape awaits at the Sharavati Backwaters, a hidden gem nestled near Honnavar town in Karnataka. Unlike the thunderous Jog Falls upstream, the backwaters offer tranquility. Imagine gliding on a boat through calm waters, enveloped by lush forests teeming with birdlife.  This captivating panorama, formed by the meandering Sharavati River, is a haven for nature lovers and photographers alike. Explore the intricate network of waterways on a traditional boat tour, soaking in the tranquility of the surroundings. Easily accessible from Honnavar, the Sharavati Backwaters promise an unforgettable escape into the heart of Karnataka's natural beauty. For the adventurous, kayaking might be an option, adding a touch of untamed spirit to your exploration.

Name: Shree Bhadrakali Temple
Description: Standing guard over the entrance to the temple town of Gokarna in Karnataka, the Shree Bhadrakali Temple is a powerful presence steeped in local legend.  This isn't your typical serene temple.  Shree Bhadrakali is worshipped as a fierce embodiment of the divine feminine, depicted with fiery eyes and weapons in hand, symbolizing protection from evil.  The two lion statues flanking the entrance and the warrior figures further emphasize the temple's association with strength.  While details about the temple's origin are elusive, stories abound about the goddess Bhadrakali arriving to defend Gokarna from demons.  Today, the temple is a vibrant hub, especially on Fridays, attracting devotees seeking blessings and a connection with this powerful deity.  So, if you find yourself in Gokarna, embrace the unique energy of the Shree Bhadrakali Temple and delve into the town's fascinating mythology.

Name: Sharavati Valley Wildlife Sanctuary
Description: Nestled within the verdant Western Ghats of Karnataka, the Sharavati Valley Wildlife Sanctuary sprawls across 431 square kilometers, beckoning nature lovers.  The landscape itself is a masterpiece - a canvas of lush Southern Tropical Evergreen and Semi-evergreen forests blanketing the valleys, with grassy hilltops adding a touch of variety.  The mighty Sharavati River carves its path through the sanctuary, culminating in the awe-inspiring Jog Falls, a 253-meter cascade.  But the true magic lies in the wildlife - tigers and leopards prowl the dense forests, while gaurs and elephants add to the majestic presence.  Spotted deer, barking deer, and playful lion-tailed macaques complete the menagerie, and the symphony of bird calls fills the air.  Beyond the thrill of wildlife spotting, the sanctuary offers serenity with boat rides on the reservoir behind the Linganamakki Dam and exploration of the tranquil backwaters of Honnemaradu and Sigandur.  From breathtaking waterfalls to diverse animals and peaceful escapes, the Sharavati Valley Wildlife Sanctuary promises an unforgettable adventure.
Address: 2WQC+J9J, Aralagodu To Kanchikai Temple Road, Halethota, Karnataka 577421
